about_data.title: W CONSERVATORY TRAINING RESIDENCY
about_data.description: W Conservatory, the training residency of NYO-China, is designed to develop individual members’ skills as musicians and to prepare the orchestra as a whole for its concert tour. Members will participate in a two-week training program, consisting of sectional rehearsals led by a world-class faculty of coaches and full orchestra rehearsals under the direction NYO-China’s music director and guest conductor. Members will also have access to other learning and exchange opportunities such as master classes, recreational chamber music readings, weekend concert excursions, and social interactions with NYO-USA.

about_data.title: CONCERT TOUR OF CHINA
about_data.description: NYO-China’s concert tour will last for one week immediately following its debut performance in Carnegie Hall on July 22nd. Upon arrival in China, the orchestra will perform in premier venues throughout the country, including the National Centre for the Performing Arts (NCPA) in Beijing, the Shanghai Grand Theatre, and the Guangzhou Opera House. This tour will showcase the orchestra on an international level and allow NYO-China’s musicians to expand the reach of this remarkable cultural exchange to audiences at home.

headlining_artists.title: Ludovic Morlot
headlining_artists.subtitle: Guest Conductor
headlining_artists.description: Ludovic Morlot is a bright star among a new generation of international conductors, serving as the principal conductor of the Seattle Symphony and a frequent guest conductor of the orchestras of Boston, New York, Chicago, and Los Angeles. Prior to his tenure at the Seattle Symphony, Maestro Morlot served as the conductor-in-residence at the Orchestre National de Lyon under David Robertson from 2002 to 2004 where he led ONL’s two youth orchestras. Further achievements include being awarded the Seiji Ozawa Fellowship in conducting at the Tanglewood Music Festival in 2002 and being inducted into the Royal Academy of Music in 2004. Beyond his duties at the Seattle Symphony, Maestro Morlot is also the chair of orchestral conducting studies at the University of Washington. As guest conductor of NYO-China, he will lead the youth ensemble beginning with their dress rehearsals and through their public performances at Carnegie Hall and in China. As a highly celebrated conductor with an enduring interest in working with students, Maestro Morlot’s participation in the project provides NYO-China’s members the opportunity to play under one of the world’s best.

headlining_artists.title: Chen Lin
headlining_artists.subtitle: Music Director and Chief Artistic Advisor
headlining_artists.description: A professor at the Central Conservatory of Music in Beijing and a well-respected conductor of many youth and international music ensembles, Chen Lin joins the NYO-China team as its music director and chief artistic advisor. After studying with the acclaimed Yu Feng at the Central Conservatory of Music, she served as a guest conductor for a number of renowned ensembles, including the symphony orchestras of Beijing, Shanghai, Shenzhen, and Vancouver. She was also selected as a Fellowship Conductor for the Tanglewood Music Festival in 2002. In addition to her achievements in conducting, Chen Lin taught as a professor of conducting at the University of Cincinnati College Conservatory of Music. Her extensive experience in both the United States and China makes her an invaluable resource for NYO-China’s students as conductor, mentor, and advisor. At W Conservatory, Ms. Chen will lead full orchestral rehearsals in the days leading up to Maestro Morlot’s arrival and oversee the orchestra’s faculty throughout the preparation process. Ms. Chen also serves as an integral artistic advisor to the NYO-China project, providing guidance and direction on matters related to curriculum, faculty, staff, and repertoire.

image_grid.title: FULL ORCHESTRAL REHEARSALS
image_grid.text: Full orchestral rehearsals form the core of the W Conservatory program and will allow students to train as one orchestra under the leadership of our music director [Music Director] and, later, our principal conductor [Conductor]. Held daily throughout the three weeks, these rehearsals will develop our student musicians into an orchestra capable of performing on a world stage. No less important, they will help members of NYO-China to develop the listening, communication, and leadership skills that are essential for a consummate orchestral player.

image_grid.title: SECTIONAL REHEARSALS
image_grid.text: Sectional rehearsals will be held every other day and will be led by coaches selected from the faculty of major American conservatories and the principal ranks of premier American orchestras. These coaching sessions will allow each sectional group to work in isolation, enabling them to sort out the repertoire’s technical challenges and thereafter cultivate a unified sectional sound and interpretation. In addition, coaches will spend time discussing common audition excerpts and repertoire, providing members the opportunity to learn first hand from a master of their instrument.

image_grid.title: MASTER CLASSES
image_grid.text: Master classes will be conducted by faculty coaches throughout the week and will provide students the chance to both perform for their peers as a soloist and observe the mentorship process as an audience member. Furthermore, this is our student’s opportunity to publicly demonstrate their growth as a musician through performing excerpts of their choice. Finally, by working individually with their faculty coaches on a regular basis, students will be able to develop personal and musical relationships that will benefit them well beyond the conclusion of W Conservatory.

image_grid.title: SEMINARS AND WORKSHOPS
image_grid.text: Seminars and workshops will be given on a variety of topics, including musical history and interpretation, performance psychology, and professional music opportunities. Our seminars will also focus on navigating the music education system in the United States and will allow students to meet and learn from the administrators and faculty of the nation’s most prominent music conservatories. Our workshops will place an emphasis on interactivity, encouraging students to think critically about their aspirations as musicians and to acquire the physical, mental, and interpretive skills necessary to realize their goals.

image_grid.title: INTERACTIONS WITH NYO-USA
image_grid.text: NYO-China was inspired by the remarkable success of Carnegie Hall’s NYO-USA and has been modeled after it so as to achieve similar benefits for its members. As the two programs are so similar in design and purpose, the NYO-China curriculum will include a number of opportunities for social interactions with NYO-USA. Members will have the chance to discuss their experiences with their American counterparts and, furthermore, rehearse and perform together in small groups, participating in an especially meaningful cultural exchange.

image_grid.title: CULTURAL EXCURSIONS
image_grid.text: Beyond the development of members’ individual musical prowess, W Conservatory is also meant to expose students to the broader culture within which they will perform. To this end, students will have the opportunity to attend chaperoned weekend excursions to a wide variety of musical and cultural attractions in the Greater New York Metropolitan Area. Destinations will include concerts by premier American orchestras, exhibitions by modern and classical dance troupes, performances by musical theatre companies, and recitals by touring chamber orchestras.

concert_tour_data.name: NYO-China
concert_tour_data.place_description: Located in Midtown Manhattan, Carnegie Hall is, without question, the most famous performance venue in the United States, if not the world. Constructed in 1891, the legendary concert hall has been home to hundreds of musical debuts – of composers’ newest works and of young soloists who would later become internationally renowned stars. Students will make their own debut on the Ronald O. Perelman Stage in the 2800-seat Isaac Stern Auditorium, thereby taking their own place in this fine tradition.

concert_tour_data.name: NYO-China
concert_tour_data.place_description: The National Grand Theatre, otherwise known as the National Centre for the Performing Arts (NCPA), is the flagship arts complex of the People’s Republic of China. Completed in 2007, this venue has already attracted a formidable catalogue of artists who seek to call this concert hall their home. An architectural wonder surrounded by an artificial lake adjacent to Tiananmen Square, the NCPA is home to three large performance spaces, including the Music Hall which seats approximately 2000 people.

concert_tour_data.name: NYO-China
concert_tour_data.place_description: The Shanghai Grand Theatre is one of the largest and most impressive concert halls in China. Since its opening almost two decades ago, the theatre has staged over 6000 performances of operas, musicals, ballets, symphonies, chamber music concerts, spoken dramas, and various traditional Chinese operas. Centrally located in People’s Square, the venue is a highly recognizable cultural icon for the people of Shanghai. Its Lyric Theatre, the largest of its three halls, is able to seat 1800 individuals.

concert_tour_data.name: NYO-China
concert_tour_data.place_description: The Guangzhou Opera House is one of the most visually stunning concert venues in the world. Designed by famed architect Zaha Hadid, the opera house ranks as one of the three largest performance venues in China (along with the National Grand Theatre in Beijing and the Shanghai Grand Theatre). While it was only inaugurated in 2010, the venue has already attracted many exceptional performances in the past half-decade. The largest of its several auditoriums – the Opera Hall – comfortably seats over 1800 people.
